RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Possui doutorado em Matemática Aplicada e Computação pela Cranfield University, Reino Unido (2006), mestrado em Matemática Aplicada pela Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul - UFRGS (2001), e bacharelado em Matemática Aplicada e Computacional pela Universidade de Santa Cruz do Sul - UNISC (1998). Realizou projeto de pós-doutorado no Instituto Tecnológico de Aeronáutica (ITA). Atualmente, é pesquisadora associada do ICL (Innovative Computing Laboratory), na Universidade do Tennessee, em Knoxville, TN, EUA. Suas principais áreas de interesse são computação paralela e distribuída, computação de alta performance (HPC), álgebra linear numérica, sistemas de equações lineares, algoritmos e métodos numéricos.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Holds a Doctor of Philosophy degree in Applied Mathematics and Computing from Cranfield University, United Kingdom, a Bachelor of Science degree in Applied Mathematics and Computing from Universidade de Santa Cruz do Sul - UNISC and a Master of Science degree in Applied Mathematics from Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul - UFRGS. Before pursuing her MSc, worked in the publishing industry as assistant manager and computer graphics designer. Also worked as a self-employed software developer. Before starting her PhD, she worked in academia as a lecturer for Universidade Regional Integrada do Alto Uruguai e das Missões, teaching graduate and undergraduate students, and as a researcher and technical assistant for CESUP - National Supercomputing Centre of Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul. In the United Kingdom, she worked for AspenTech and Cranfield University as a research collaborator. In 2006, she joined the Gas Turbine Group of the Aeronautical Institute of Technology - ITA as a postdoctoral researcher. Currently, works as researcher at Federal University of Uberlandia. Her main areas of interest are parallel computing and numerical methods.

PESQUISA-E-DESENVOLVIMENTO.NOME-ORGAO: Centro de Ciências Exatas e Tecnologia

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
The Parallel Linear Algebra for Scalable Multi-core Architectures (PLASMA) project aims to address the critical and highly disruptive situation that is facing the Linear Algebra and High Performance Computing community due to the introduction of multi-core architectures.
PLASMA s ultimate goal is to create software frameworks that enable programmers to simplify the process of developing applications that can achieve both high performance and portability across a range of new architectures.
The development of programming models that enforce asynchronous, out of order scheduling of operations is the concept used as the basis for the definition of a scalable yet highly efficient software framework for Computational Linear Algebra applications.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES:
The Parallel Linear Algebra for Scalable Multi-core Architectures (PLASMA) project aims to address the critical and highly disruptive situation that is facing the Linear Algebra and High Performance Computing community due to the introduction of multi-core architectures.
PLASMA s ultimate goal is to create software frameworks that enable programmers to simplify the process of developing applications that can achieve both high performance and portability across a range of new architectures.
The development of programming models that enforce asynchronous, out of order scheduling of operations is the concept used as the basis for the definition of a scalable yet highly efficient software framework for Computational Linear Algebra applications.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: An efficient distributed randomized algorithm for solving large dense symmetric indefinite linear systems
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: An efficient distributed randomized algorithm for solving large dense symmetric indefinite linear systems

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Abstract: Randomized algorithms are gaining ground in high-performance computing applications as they have the potential to outperform deterministic methods, while still providing accurate results. We propose a randomized solver for distributed multicore architectures to efficiently solve large dense symmetric indefinite linear systems that are encountered, for instance, in parameter estimation problems or electromagnetism simulations. The contribution of this paper is to propose efficient kernels for applying random butterfly transformations and a new distributed implementation combined with a runtime (PaRSEC) that automatically adjusts data structures, data mappings, and the scheduling as systems scale up. Both the parallel distributed solver and the supporting runtime environment are innovative. To our knowledge, the randomization approach associated with this solver has never been used in public domain software for symmetric indefinite systems. The underlying runtime framework allows seamless data mapping and task scheduling, mapping its capabilities to the underlying hardware features of heterogeneous distributed architectures. The performance of our software is similar to that obtained for symmetric positive definite systems, but requires only half the execution time and half the amount of data storage of a general dense solver.

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-OUTRA-PRODUCAO.TITULO: Otimização dos Custos de Impressão em Offset Plana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Monografia apresentada como requisito paricial para conclusão do Curso de Matemática Aplicada e Computacional na Universidade de Santa Cruz do Sul.

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-OUTRA-PRODUCAO.TITULO: O Método Iterativo GMRES em Blocos Dinâmicos para a Solução de Sistemas Lineares com Múltiplos Termos Independentes em Computadores Paralelos
DADOS-BASICOS-DE-OUTRA-PRODUCAO.TITULO-INGLES: Iterative Method GMRES in Dynamic Blocks for Solving Systems of Linear Equations with Multiple Right-hand-sides in Parallel Computers

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Neste trabalho apresentamos o GMRES em Blocos Dinâmicos, um método iterativo para resolver sistemas de equações lineares com múltiplos termos independentes, e a implementação do seu algoritmo em computadores paralelos. Este novo método é uma variação do GMRES em bloco de Saad e tem como principal característica a deflação da dimensão dos blocos, através da detecção da convergência de um ou mais sistemas ao final de cada iteração e através da identificação dos blocos que possuem colunas linearmente dependentes, a cada passo do processo de Arnoldi. A deflação tem como conseqüência a redução do esforço computacional necessário em todo o processo de solução. São desenvolvidos dois algoritmos, um usando a fatoração Householder QR e outro usando a fatoração RRQR, proposta por Bischof e Quintana-Ortí. Resultados numéricos são obtidos para problemas com matrizes de coeficientes densas e esparsas, demonstrando a eficiência do novo método.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: In this work we present the Dynamic-Block-GMRES, an iterative method for the solution of systems of linear equations with multiple right-hand sides and the implementation of its algorithm on parallel computers. This new method is a \linebreak variation of the Block-GMRES method due to Saad and has as its main characteristic the deflation on the dimension of the blocks, through the detection of convergence of one or more systems at the end of each iteration, and through the identification of the blocks containing linearly dependent columns, in each step of the Arnoldi process. The deflation leads to a reduction in the amount of work needed as a whole. We develop two algorithms, one using the Householder QR factorization and an other using the RRQR factorization, proposed by Bischof and Quintana-Ortí. Numerical results are obtained for problems with dense and sparse coefficient matrices demonstrating the efficiency of the new method.

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-OUTRA-PRODUCAO.TITULO: Parallel Unstructured Solvers for Linear Partial Differential Equations
DADOS-BASICOS-DE-OUTRA-PRODUCAO.TITULO-INGLES: Parallel Unstructured Solvers for Linear Partial Differential Equations

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
This thesis presents the development of a parallel algorithm to solve symmetric systems of linear equations and the computational implementation of a parallel partial differential equations solver for unstructured meshes. The proposed method, called distributive conjugate gradient - DCG, is based on a single-level domain decomposition method and the conjugate gradient method to obtain a highly scalable parallel algorithm.
An overview on methods for the discretization of domains and partial differential equations is given. The partition and refinement of meshes is discussed and the formulation of the weighted residual method for two- and three-dimensions presented. Some of the methods to solve systems of linear equations are introduced, highlighting the conjugate gradient method and domain decomposition methods. A parallel unstructured PDE solver is proposed and its actual implementation presented. Emphasis is given to the data partition adopted and the scheme used for communication among adjacent subdomains is explained. A series of experiments in processor scalability is also reported.
The derivation and parallelization of DCG are presented and the method validated throughout numerical experiments. The method capabilities and limitations were investigated by the solution of the Poisson equation with various source terms. The experimental results obtained using the parallel solver developed as part of this work show that the algorithm presented is accurate and highly scalable, achieving roughly linear parallel speed-up in many of the cases tested.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES:
This thesis presents the development of a parallel algorithm to solve symmetric systems of linear equations and the computational implementation of a parallel partial differential equations solver for unstructured meshes. The proposed method, called distributive conjugate gradient - DCG, is based on a single-level domain decomposition method and the conjugate gradient method to obtain a highly scalable parallel algorithm.
An overview on methods for the discretization of domains and partial differential equations is given. The partition and refinement of meshes is discussed and the formulation of the weighted residual method for two- and three-dimensions presented. Some of the methods to solve systems of linear equations are introduced, highlighting the conjugate gradient method and domain decomposition methods. A parallel unstructured PDE solver is proposed and its actual implementation presented. Emphasis is given to the data partition adopted and the scheme used for communication among adjacent subdomains is explained. A series of experiments in processor scalability is also reported.
The derivation and parallelization of DCG are presented and the method validated throughout numerical experiments. The method capabilities and limitations were investigated by the solution of the Poisson equation with various source terms. The experimental results obtained using the parallel solver developed as part of this work show that the algorithm presented is accurate and highly scalable, achieving roughly linear parallel speed-up in many of the cases tested.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Novel algorithm to calculate nearest wall distance

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Proceedings of 7th International Conference of Numerical Analysis and Applied Mathematics (ICNAAM 2009) - Extended abstract to be published in a special volume of AIP Conference Proceedings

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: A parallel tiled solver for dense symmetric indefinite systems on multicore architectures
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: A parallel tiled solver for dense symmetric indefinite systems on multicore architectures

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: 2012 IEEE International Parallel & Distributed Processing Symposium

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: We describe an efficient and innovative parallel tiled algorithm for solving symmetric indefinite systems on multicore architectures. This solver avoids pivoting by using a multiplicative preconditioning based on symmetric randomization. This randomization prevents the communication overhead due to pivoting, is computationally inexpensive and requires very little storage. Following randomization, a tiled LDLT factorization is used that reduces synchronization by using static or dynamic scheduling. We compare Gflop/s performance of our solver with other types of factorizations on a current multicore machine and we provide tests on accuracy using LAPACK test cases.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: We describe an efficient and innovative parallel tiled algorithm for solving symmetric indefinite systems on multicore architectures. This solver avoids pivoting by using a multiplicative preconditioning based on symmetric randomization. This randomization prevents the communication overhead due to pivoting, is computationally inexpensive and requires very little storage. Following randomization, a tiled LDLT factorization is used that reduces synchronization by using static or dynamic scheduling. We compare Gflop/s performance of our solver with other types of factorizations on a current multicore machine and we provide tests on accuracy using LAPACK test cases.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-SOFTWARE.FINALIDADE: Software projetado para calcular e minimizar o custo de produção de impressos em offsets planas, a partir de dados previamente cadastrados
Permite o cadastro de pesquisa de opinião pública, a partir de dados coletados e informados ao sistema, compila os mesmos e fornece relatórios diversos

Sistema Administrativo contendo módulos para gerenciamento de clientes, fornecedores, orçamentos, produtos, estoque, pedidos, notas fiscais, contas a pagar e recerber, controle do arquivo de documentos e cadastros diversos.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Software desenvolvido no período de 1992 a 1998.
